dxf2svg.util
Class DxfSearchEngine

java.lang.Object
  dxf2svg.util.DxfSearchEngine
public class DxfSearchEngine
extends java.lang.Object

Searches for patterns in an ASCII AutoCAD DXF file.

How to use the search engine:

  1. Create a DxfSearchEngine object.
  2. Pass a DXF file handle to the engine (in a loop if necessary).
  3. Create pattern (regular expression) and pass it to the DxfSearchEngine's find(java.util.regex.Pattern) method.
Use the findNext() method to find additional instances of a search pattern. You may also explicitly test a file for searchability with the isAsciiDxf() method, but this test is called before the find() method is run.

This class can be made to searches sensitive to certain group codes. This allows the implementer to specify the exact group code that the expected data can be found in. The default is to search for patterns only in group codes of '1' - general text Strings. Pass a search code of '999' to additionally search comments.

This class can search for any type of data within the DXF file, but all returned values are expressed as Java Strings.

Here is a list of things that you can do to customize searches:

  1. Limit searches to a specific layer.
  2. Search all layers by passing null as a search layer.
  3. Search specific sections of the DXF.

Version:
1.1 April 21, 2004
Author:
Andrew Nisbet

validLayer

sectionInclude

protected int sectionInclude
This value allows you to exclude a particular section from a search. This is useful to allow you specify sections that will have data that you are interested in. This will automatically exclude other sections from the search. Skipping a search of the header will be produce fewer false hits. For example: if you were to perform a search of the entire DXF for text strings that occur on layer '0', and you want to collect the group code 10 and 20 for each hit, you will get positive hits if HEADER is allowed to be searched. You will pick up the autocad version number for example and several unrelated 10 and 20 values. The reason is that there is a group code of 8 in the header that is not related to the header but is usually set to '0'. All other entities use the group code 8 to indicate the layer they are on. This is how layer searches are identified. The HEADER section is also peppered with 10 and 20 values that to the header are just double precision values but to entities are x any y coordinates for the location of the anchor points for entities. The sectionInclude variable contains all the areas you wish to search and is controllable from the addSectionToSearch(int) and the removeSectionFromSearch(int) methods.

Constant Field Values

HEADER

public static final int HEADER
HEADER contains all the variables that describe the state of AutoCAD at the time the DXF was made. Removing this section from the search criteria will eliminate a lot of false hits for searches for stuff on layer '0'.

See Also:

BLOCKS

public static final int BLOCKS
The Blocks section is an important section to search for visible content in a DXF. It contains entity descriptions and grouping information for blocks.

See Also:

public static final int ENTITIES
This is the most important section to search if you want to collect information from the visible data in the DXF.

Method Detail

displaySearchLayer

public void displaySearchLayer()
Prints out the layer that searches will be bound to.

displaySearchSections

public void displaySearchSections()
This method displays the sections that are going to be searched.

removeSectionFromSearch

public void removeSectionFromSearch(int section)
This method allows you to remove sections from the search criteria. The default is to search the ENTITIES section and the BLOCKS section so if you called this method with the argument BLOCKS, the BLOCKS section would be dropped from the search criteria and only the ENTITIES section would remain.

addSectionToSearch

public void addSectionToSearch(int section)
This method allows you to add a specific section to the search criteria. The default is to search the ENTITIES section and the BLOCKS section.

setDxfFile

public void setDxfFile(java.io.File dxfFile)
Allows the client to specify a DXF to search. All previous search criteria are reset.

findNext

public java.lang.String findNext()
Searches the next instance of a previously defined pattern. If no previous pattern has been defined, the return value will be null and a error message will be issued.

find

public java.lang.String find(java.util.regex.Pattern p)
Searches the target DXF file for the argument search pattern. Any layer sensitive searches are reset. If you require a layer sensitive search to be repeated use findOnLayer(String,Pattern).

Returns:
String value of the first match found or null if the pattern was not found. use findNext() to search for additional matches of the pattern.

findOnLayer

public java.lang.String findOnLayer(java.lang.String layer,
                                    java.util.regex.Pattern p)
This method allows the client to sensitively isolate searches to a specific layer. The behaviour is as follows: using this method sets a layer to search on subsequent calls to find(java.util.regex.Pattern) or findNext() or find(java.util.regex.Pattern) all will confine searches to this layer as well. To remove this behaviour, call the method again with the argument set to null.

Parameters:
p - Pattern of text to search for.
Returns:
layer value of the first match found or null if the pattern was not found case insensitive.

reset

public void reset()
Resets the seach engine (but not the already entered search codes). This method clears a search sensitivity for a specific layer, reset the search to the top of the file ready for searching all layers.

isLayerSearch

protected boolean isLayerSearch()
This method will report if a search by a layer is in progress.

find

public boolean find(java.util.Vector results)
Makes a search of a specific layer for pre-applied group codes (see addSearchCode(Integer) for setting group codes that you are interested in. The Hashtable results contains all matching group codes in order that they were entered and the values that were found. This search is recommended as it is very fast and more efficient than find().

Parameters:
results - A user supplied container of all the matching group codes and values delimited by a ':'.
Returns:
true if search produced at least one match and false otherwise.
Since:
1.1

find

public boolean find(java.lang.String layer,
                    java.util.Vector results)
Makes a search of a specific layer for pre-applied group codes (see addSearchCode(Integer) for setting group codes that you are interested in. The Hashtable results contains all matching group codes in order that they were entered and the values that were found. This search is recommended as it is very fast and more efficient than find().

Parameters:
layer - String name of the layer to search. A null value will cause the search engine to search all layers.
results - a container of all the matching group codes and values delimited by a ':'.
Returns:
true if search produced at least one match and false otherwise.
Since:
1.1

matchGroupCodes

protected boolean matchGroupCodes(java.util.Vector buff,
                                  java.util.Vector results)
This method takes a buffer of groupcodes from the DXF, searches for all of interesting groupcodes and when one is found adds it to the second argument Hashtable. If the buffer is empty results is unchanged.

isEligibleForSearch

protected boolean isEligibleForSearch(java.util.Vector buff)
Determines if this layer is the layer we wish to search on.

Returns:
true if the buffer contains a layer identified for a search or no search layer is identified and false if it is not the indicated layer, if the buffer is empty or null.

readSection

protected boolean readSection(java.io.BufferedReader bRead,
                              java.util.Vector buff)
                       throws java.io.IOException
Reads an entire section of a DXF file. A section consists of all of the group codes which start with group code zero '0' and continue until the next group code zero.

Returns:
false if the section was an end of file section code and true if the section was read. The vector buffer will be filled with the content of the section without the initil group code and value, if the buffer is not null. The method will
Throws:
java.io.IOException

setCurrentSection

protected void setCurrentSection(java.lang.String value)
Sets the current SECTION of the DXF we are currently in.

getCurrentSection

public int getCurrentSection()
Returns the current section of the DXF being read as an integer.

find

protected java.lang.String find()
This method does the actual searching of the Dxf file and is never called directly.

addSearchCode

public void addSearchCode(java.lang.Integer i)
Allows significant codes to be identified. All Strings in DXF are preceeded by a code value that indicates what type of String they are. Codes like '0' represent SECTION strings Codes like 999 are comment strings.

The default search code is '1' and it does not need to be added for the search to be performed. To remove a search code use the removeSearchCode(java.lang.Integer) method.

removeSearchCode

public boolean removeSearchCode(java.lang.Integer i)
This method removes a search code from the list of codes to search stack. If there are multipule codes of the same value only the first will be removed, so in that case there may be a requirement to call this method until the it returns false.

displaySearchCodes

public void displaySearchCodes()
Displays the codes that this object has been trained to focus on as significant.

isAsciiDxf

public boolean isAsciiDxf()
Returns true if the file is an ASCII DXF file, and false if it is anything else.

isInterestingCode

protected boolean isInterestingCode(java.lang.String s)
Returns true if the passed code string contains a code we are interested in searching.

Throws:
java.lang.NumberFormatException - if the String does not contain a valid integer.
